Award.AbstractNarration: A Research Experience for Undergraduates (REU) Sites award has been made to UCSF that will provide research training for 10 students, for 10 weeks during the summers of 2013- 2016. The program offers state of the art hands-on training in the methods and logic of Molecular Biosciences with a goal of facilitating successful transition to graduate research. Interdisciplinary faculty expertise is drawn broadly from the fields of genetics/genomics; biochemistry; cell/developmental biology; systems/synthetic biology and bioengineering. The centerpiece of the program is an intensive research experience to learn modern technologies and how to use them creatively to solve research problems. REU students have access to a rich array of facilities for their research. Students also participate in seminars and workshops including: responsible conduct in research, professional communication skills, career opportunities in industry and academia, and the graduate school application process. Additionally students meet weekly in small groups with a teaching assistant to learn to communicate science and digest the research experience. The program culminates with oral and poster presentations. The program aims to increase the scientific workforce by recruiting groups underrepresented in science including minority/disadvantaged/disabled students, those from colleges with limited research opportunities, and first in family to attend college. Recruiting strategies include attendance at national meetings (SACNAS, ABRCMS), visits to campuses in the California State University system, website information, and mailings to universities across the country. Students are selected based on academic record, research performance, and potential for outstanding research. Letters from previous research mentors, including those of mentors from previous summer programs are of particular importance. Students are tracked to determine their continued interest in their academic field of study, their career paths, and the lasting influences of the research experience. Information about the program will be assessed by various means, including use of an REU common assessment tool available to BIO-funded REU PIs. More information is available by visiting http://graduate.ucsf.edu/content/summer-research-opportunities or by contacting the PI (Dr. Carol Gross: cgrossucsf@gmail.com) or the co-PI (Dr. Hana El Samad: Hana.El-Samad@ucsf.edu)

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal of UCSF’s NSF REU is to prepare bright, driven young scientists from diverse backgrounds, to successfully apply to and enroll in highly competitive doctorate programs, and succeed in graduate school and beyond. Over the course of 4 years, UCSF’s NSF-REU has supported nearly 40 young scientists from across the country. These students come from underrepresented or socioeconomically disadvantaged backgrounds, and in some cases have not previously had the opportunity to participate in a research-intensive environment like UCSF. During the program, students build a strong sense of self-confidence in their ability to be successful scientists while contributing to world-class research programs.

The program is designed to provide a comprehensive graduate student-like experience, which prepares them to tackle the challenges and rewards of a PhD. Participants are fully integrated into their research labs as young scientists in training. They plan experiments, present their ideas and research results, and learn how to read, write and think like scientists. Participants are also provided with housing, access to on-campus student health, and receive a stipend for the summer, all of which are crucial to ensuring participants can focus their attention on their research experience.

NSF-REU participants uniformly reported an overwhelmingly positive experience. They form long-term relationships with each other, and with the students and faculty they work with. All participants indicate their experiences built their self-confidence and bolstered their passion for scientific discovery. In many cases, participants indicate they have renewed their commitment and interest in pursuing a PhD. Of all UCSF NSF-REU participants who applied to UCSF more than half were admitted. More than 80% of NSF-REU participants went on to enroll in PhD programs at UCSF and elsewhere.

Those who mentor the NSF-REU participants also report an overwhelmingly positive experience. Current UCSF graduate students serve as student advisors, offering advice and support to program participants. Within the lab, faculty and students guide program participants through their experiments. In all cases these mentors report that working with our participants is a rewarding experience, and are impressed with the students’ drive and abilities.

In 2016, UCSF Chancellor Sam Hawgood shared the impact and impressive results of the NSF-REU program with the wider UCSF community in his “State of the University” address. In this address, the program was recognized for its impact on young scientists and its contribution to strengthening the diversity of our graduate programs. We look forward to continuing our work, with the support of NSF, so that we can prepare the next generation of scientific leaders.
